DOCNAME: CASE OF HARALAMBIDIS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant used to be president of the board of directors and managing director of the first applicant company and manager of the second applicant company . The first applicant company , the full title of which is PERSON , ORG Transports and ORG ( ανώνυμος εταιρία ) , was incorporated under NORP law . It was set up in DATE . The second applicant company , the full title of which is FAC ( εταιρία περιορισμένης ευθύνης ) , was also incorporated under NORP law . It was set up in DATE .

CARDINAL . DATE the second applicant company transported cloth from outside ORG into GPE and then to GPE . DATE the customs authorities , suspecting that criminal offences had been committed in the course of this activity , asked for and were granted leave from the local public prosecutor to start a preliminary inquiry .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE criminal proceedings were instituted against the first applicant and others for contraband , forgery and fraud against the ORG . The first applicant was in essence charged with bringing the cloth into GPE as goods in transit for GPE and then changing its origin by using forged documents in order “ to export ” it to GPE as NORP and avoid paying customs duties . The first applicant company appeared as the NORP “ exporter ” of the cloth .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the customs authorities of GPE , considering that the first applicant in his capacity as representative of the CARDINAL applicant companies had committed the customs offence of contraband , decided to impose on him fines of a total amount of CARDINAL drachmas . Fines of a total amount of CARDINAL drachmas were also imposed on PERSON , an employee of the second applicant company and Mr GPE , a customs broker . The customs authorities also decided that customs duties of a total amount of MONEY were due for the importation of the cloth in GPE . The first applicant as representative of the CARDINAL applicant companies was to be jointly and severally liable for the payment of the fines imposed on PERSON and GPE and of the customs duties ( decisions ORG . PERSON and DATE ) . The duties and fines in question were to be recovered in accordance with the LAW for ORG .

CARDINAL . The first applicant and the CARDINAL applicant companies immediately lodged appeals ( προσφυγές ) in ORG ( ORG ) of PERSON . The court requested the competent administrative authorities to compile a case - file , which they did on DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicants then tried unsuccessfully to obtain various documents concerning the transport of the cloth in question from the customs authorities .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant addressed himself to the investigating judge of GPE asking for his assistance in this matter . The investigating judge asked the customs authorities of PERSON to provide the documents in question . On CARDINAL DATE the authorities replied that some could not be found ( VOLET CARDINAL of ORG CARDINAL ) while others did not concern the applicants ( application for a reloading permit No CARDINAL ) . However , the applicants had already received a letter dated DATE from the customs authorities of GPE to the effect that the NORP authorities had sent to the LOC authorities some of the documents that the LOC authorities could not find .

CARDINAL . In the meantime the indictments chamber of the first instance criminal court ( PERSON ) of GPE decided that the first applicant should be tried by the CARDINAL - member ORG ( ORG ) of GPE , sitting as a first instance court , for forgery and fraud and by the CARDINAL - member first instance criminal court ( PERSON ) of GPE for contraband . PERSON and CARDINAL others were indicted as well . The applicant and his co - accused appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the indictments chamber of ORG ( Συμβούλιο Εφετών ) of GPE decided that the applicant and the others could not be tried for contraband because the cloth in question had technically never been imported into or exported from GPE . GPE had never been its destination , it had been brought into GPE in transit and had eventually left GPE for GPE . As a result , no customs duties were due to the NORP authorities and the crime of contraband could not have been committed . Nevertheless , the chamber decided that the applicant and his coaccused should be tried for forgery and fraud .

CARDINAL . The trial commenced on DATE . The applicant testified , inter alia , that “ he had gone to the customs office in GPE , GPE to ask for the documents but was told that he lacked locus standi and the matter was internal ” . On DATE the CARDINAL - member ORG decided to adjourn the trial in order to obtain expert evidence on the question of forgery .
CARDINAL . In DATE there was a fire on the premises of the first instance ORG , which , as a result , had to be relocated .

CARDINAL . The applicants ' appeals against the decisions of DATE and CARDINAL June DATE of the customs authorities of GPE imposing customs duties and fines were heard on DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE the threemember first instance ORG ( ORG ) of GPE quashed the decisions of DATE and DATE of the customs authorities of GPE . The court considered that the first applicant had not committed the customs offence of contraband because the cloth had entered into GPE in transit and no customs duties were due to the NORP authorities . Moreover , the intention of the applicant was to defraud the NORP authorities and not to deprive the NORP authorities of income due ( decisions ORG . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE and DATE ) . The customs authorities appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the third applicant company closed down its operations .
CARDINAL . On DATE the CARDINAL - member ORG of GPE acquitted the applicant of the forgery and fraud charges .

CARDINAL . On DATE the CARDINAL - member ORG ( ORG ) of GPE , by majority , decided to uphold the customs authorities ' appeal . The court considered that the effect of the first applicant 's and his collaborators ' actions was to change the origin of the cloth into NORP . As a result , the cloth had technically been imported into GPE . However , no customs duties had been paid and , as a result , the customs offence of contraband had been committed . The court , however , reduced the amount of the fines to be paid by the first applicant in his capacity as representative of the CARDINAL applicant companies to CARDINAL drachmas and the global fine for which the first applicant was jointly and severally liable to MONEY . CARDINAL judge disagreed . He considered that the contraband offence had not been committed and referred to the findings of the criminal court of appeal ( decisions ORG . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , FAC , DATE , CARDINAL and DATE ) .
CARDINAL . The first applicant and the CARDINAL applicant companies appealed in cassation to ORG PERSON της PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . The appeals were set for hearing by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , ORG issued decision No . CARDINAL on an appeal in cassation by the applicants concerning a fine imposed by the customs authorities on another occasion . CARDINAL of the applicants appealed against decision No . CARDINAL before ORG ( GPE PERSON ) on the ground that in another case ORG ( Αρειος Πάγος ) had interpreted LAW in a different manner .
CARDINAL . On DATE the customs authorities ordered that the first applicant should not be allowed to travel out of GPE , because of his debts to the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant requested the public prosecutor of GPE to order the customs authorities to give him certain documents . The prosecutor transmitted the applicant 's request to the customs authorities of GPE , which complied . Among the documents provided by the customs authorities were the VOLETS CARDINAL of ORG and ORG DATE that the applicants had requested in DATE .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant also obtained certain documents concerning the transport of the cloth in question from the NORP authorities .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants added to their grounds of appeal in cassation the following : The NORP customs authorities had given the wrong classification to the cloth in question . As a result , the applicants had been asked to pay higher duties and fines . The applicants had been able to establish the wrong classification of the cloth on the basis of documents they had obtained from the NORP authorities . It was the correspondence exchanged between the NORP and the NORP authorities that had made the applicants realise that it was necessary to contact the latter . The applicants had had access to the correspondence in question for the first time in DATE following the intervention of the public prosecutor of GPE . If the applicants had had this information earlier they would have been able to include a relevant ground in their appeal to the first instance ORG . Moreover , ORG had not examined the applicants ' submission that the goods in question had been given a wrong classification by the customs authorities and that the customs duties had been calculated wrongly .

CARDINAL . On DATE , due to a change in the legislation , the applicants ' appeals in cassation were transferred from the Second to the Sixth ORG . A hearing was set for CARDINAL DATE , when it was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the appeal by CARDINAL of the applicants against ORG decision No . CARDINAL .
CARDINAL

CARDINAL . The applicants have claimed that the text of the decisions of ORG was “ finalised ” ( καθαρογραφή ) on DATE . However , the Government produced a certificate issued by ORG on CARDINAL DATE , whereby it is attested that the relevant judgments were finalised on DATE , certified ( θεώρηση ) on DATE and signed ( υπογραφή ) on DATE .

CARDINAL . Following the decision of ORG the first applicant company paid the sums specified in the decisions of the administrative court of appeal plus interest and default penalties as from DATE of these decisions . The applicant company claims that it paid MONEY in total . The Government claim that the company took advantage of the salutary provisions of law No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and only paid MONEY .
